text:
We are staying in Sorrento in October, I would like to see Positano, Amalfi and Ravello while we are there. Any recommendations on the best way to do that? Is it easy enough to do independently and much cheaper or is it just worth booking a tour that takes you around them for the day?

Thanks in advance☺️

comments.comment_text: Easiest and least expensive option to visit Positano is the bus. We have also taken the ferry from Sorento to Positano and Capri, which is lovely.

Look up Viator - Positano, Amalfi & Ravello…so worth it. You’re in an air conditioned bus and then they take you around to each place. You meet at 9 am and come back around 6 pm. Enough time at each location to enjoy. We just did this on Monday glad we did.
Take the ferry to Amalfi & bus or taxi to Ravello
We did it independently using the ferries and drivers provided by hotel for when it was past ferries running
Me too! Following
Elizabeth Colleen Fowler

We booked all of our excursions through the driving company. We told them what we wanted to see and They took the headache out of it and planned amazing days for us in sorrento, positano, Pompeii, hiring vesuvious, wineries, Ravello, capri, wineries, resteraunts from finding italy, amalfi, etc. She took what we wanted to do and planned the most efficient and relaxing days.. Message rosa on what's app. They were well priced and we felt well taken care of and safe!

+39 338 920 8399- Rosa
Super easy - take the bus or the boat 🥰
By Ferry from Marina Piccolo in Sorrento
We did a private driver Stefania al volante. She made suggestions of what to see in each place. We loved Ravello

Cheapest way would be to either take the ferry or the bus from Sorrento to Positano. From there you can go on to Amalfi if you want. From Amalfi, there is a bus that takes you to Ravello. That way, you can spend as much or as little time in each place as you wish before moving on.
Following
Is it better to do tour by car or by boat ?
No need for a tour but you could get a private driver or do it yourself with buses and ferries! For instance, you could go buy land, one-way, and boat on return.
We booked Amalfi Coast Transfers because we want to see Furore and other tours don’t go there. We have 8 hours to go where we went to go. It can be longer if we choose.
The ferry boat
We took the bus from Sorrento to Amalfi, then another bus to Ravello and back to Amalfi. We took the return bus to Sorrento but got off in Positano and got the boat back to Sorrento.
No your, go on your own, it’s easy.
Tour
We are doing a small boat tour of the coast! I am sure there are many different tours that offer them.
Buses from train station.
Thanks everyone, probably should have mentioned that any boats/ ferry is out as my mother in law can’t do them sure to travel sickness😅

Private driver is my choice. Expensive but it’s an indulgence!

Tips on taking a taxi from the Naples airport to our Airbnb in Sorrento? It’s ￼ reported to be about €90. I realize you have to have an agreed-upon price before hiring the taxi. Just wondering if the language barrier was a problem for those using the taxi?

Thanks!

You take the ferry to Positano and Amalfi. Nothing complicated about it. From Amalfi, you can take a bus up the mountain to Ravello. Two villages in one day is plenty. If I could only see two, they would be Positano and Ravello. I find riding the ferries very relaxing and pleasurable. Also, I personally think the sea view is far superior to what you see from the road. The bus gave me motion sickness and I have to say it was a bit scary as the roads are narrow and the bus came precariously close to the edge of the road, with an over-generous view looking a thousand feet down over the cliff.
The most exciting and fun way to see the area is to rent a Vespa scooter in Sorrento. We just got back last week and that was highlight of my trip.

We just got back in May and we did a private tour and it was wonderful. Time in each town and Tina w for lunch in Ravello. We booked thru Viator. Very nice driver and Lincoln town car. He picked us up and dropped us off back at our hotel. I hope this helps.
Janice Foxcroft

We based in Rapallo. A great jumping off point for Santa Margarita, Portofino (pictured), Camogli, even Genoa, as well as Cinque Terre, Portovenere, Lerice, Tellaro. From Rapallo, we were able to walk to the first two, while enjoying evenings in a vibrant community.

Hey dale, me and my friends spent your time residing in La Spezia. The location is very close to cinque terra and easily accessible by train, it is not at nice as cinque terra itself but if you are looking to try keep prices down i believe La Spezia is a wonderful option. I hope this helped and good luck with your planning xo

Hi Dale, We stayed in a hotel on a hill just outside of Levanto which is the next town over from Cinque Terra for four days. It was less expensive and less frenetic than any of the five towns (the crowds at some were amazing). Trains run frequently to and from the towns if walking gets too much. Also had a sand beach there as well as the pebbles. Also enjoyed the walk to Bonassola as well. Not as pretty but much less crowded and the risotto from a street cafe was one of the best I've had. You'll love Cinque Terra, it is as pretty as the pictures.

text:
We had our Coopculture Underground night tour of the Colosseum last night. I just wanted to share my experience for anyone else who’s planning on doing this. First of all, we had to book the tickets in Italian, despite stalking the website, practicing buying a few days before, setting alarms, AND trying 4 days in a row….I was unable to secure English tickets. I had read in quite a few places this was no big deal, that most tours are all English speaking people and the guide ends up doing the tour in English or else you can follow closely along with google translate. We didn’t get that lucky. Our group was ALL Italian speaking, she didn’t say one single word to us in English and Google Translate was terrible when it even worked. There was no signal in the underground. My husband and son listened to our downloaded Rick Steves app, but we all feel as though we missed out on so much. I took some amazing pictures and enjoyed just being there, but I would have really enjoyed some history and her point of view.

Also….BRING EVERYONES PASSPORT!!!! Despite 2 years of planning and research, I somehow missed this little nugget of information!!! When we went to check in, the man looking at tickets Flat. Out. Refused. To let us in. In fact he was screaming “No way, No Way” as I pleaded with him (my husband and I had our ID’s. I even may have shed a tear or two. As we were walking away to leave, my son said “Do you have pictures of our passports?” OMG!!!YES I did!!! Of course I did, why didn’t I think of that!!! My mind was 💯 focused on getting back to our Airbnb in enough time to grab the passports and get back!! Well, he saved the day!! They accepted the pictures!!

All in all it was an experience we’ll never forget, I was happy we got inside, toured the underground and went at night. The night part was amazing to me. The 8:30 tickets were perfect for lighting in pictures!!

Then northern part of Lazio, very close to Rome by train, is underappreciate
d and still awaiting to be discovered by tourists. It's a landscape of hills, small and cozy villages and beautiful, ancient villas and historical gardens - I'm thinking of Villa Lante in Bagbaia, near Vitervo. Check it out online, see what you think.

Here are a few places less than an hour train ride from Rome that you can visit for a different perspective of Italy:

* **Tivoli:** This town is home to two UNESCO World Heritage sites, Villa d'Este and Villa Adriana. Villa d'Este is known for its beautiful gardens and fountains, while Villa Adriana is an impressive Roman archaeological complex.

* **Orvieto:** This hilltop town is known for its stunning views, medieval architecture, and delicious wine. Be sure to visit the Orvieto Cathedral, which is one of the most beautiful cathedrals in Italy.

* **Viterbo:** This town is the capital of the Lazio region and is home to a number of historical sites, including the Piazza del Campo, the Rocca Albornoziana, and the Cathedral of San Lorenzo.

* **Anzio:** This seaside town is located on the coast of the Tyrrhenian Sea. It's a popular destination for swimming, sunbathing, and seafood restaurants.

* **Ostia Antica:** This ancient Roman city is located just a few kilometers from Rome. It's a fascinating place to visit to learn about Roman history and culture.

These are just a few suggestions, but there are many other great places to visit within an hour train ride of Rome. If you're looking for something less touristy, I would recommend Tivoli, Orvieto, or Viterbo. They all offer a unique perspective of Italy and are sure to leave you wanting more.
Anguillara Sabazia, it’s the town on Lake Bracciano where Everybody Loves Raymond shot their episodes in Italy. Very charming
Tivoli or Orvieto

Orvieto - so easy to get there from Rome, and it will round out your Italian itinerary beautifully. Umbrian hill town perched atop a spur of tufa, stunning cathedral, cozy trattorias with hearty food, also ceramics shops with hand painted plates and pitchers etc. Just lovely!

Ostia antica is probably less than an hour away, not far from the airport - a site with ruins that if I’m not mistaken has a site of ruins larger and older than Pompeii. Tivoli is also very nice and close to Rome. Enjoy your trip.

My 2 cents. We will be in Rome in a month and after joining this group decided to book our tours of the Vatican and the Colosseum. There wasn’t a ton available. text: Beautiful night in Termoli.

Having recently driven from the UK through France, Lake Como, Venice & now Switzerland by car, here are a few things we noticed which may be of help.

Lake Como:
Unbelievably scenic. Everywhere we went around the lake from Nesso to Varenna, Bellagio to Menaggio is glorious. Try & fit in as much sightseeing as you can.
Hire a boat - we did at Bellagio, cost around €100 for an hour. Great fun.
There are lots of areas around the lake where you can have a dip. Very cold but worth it.

Drive to Venice took around 4hrs & tolls cost us approx €30. Plenty of services en route & pre-booked car park.

Venice:
Extremely hot, very very busy but a one off! An experience like nowhere else.
If you want to go on the Grand Canal in a gondola be sure to use the gondoliers actually on the Grand Canal. The ones in the small waterways charge the same -€80 for 20m/half hour or €120 to make it to the Grand Canal as it’s further.
Have an Aperol or coffee at Piazza San Marco - most cafes/restaurants there have musicians playing whilst you sit.
Typical meal at a Trattoria (lasagne, calzone, pizza x 2, a huge beer, medium beer & large bottle of water) for 4 cost us €90.

At both Lake Como & Venice we used our card (Starling) everywhere with no problems, and took just a little cash for tips. Make sure your Airbnb/hotel room has excellent air con! Get up early before they become very very busy.

text:
I have a question about catching a taxi at the Vatican (museums) to the Rome Termini train station, please!

We are arriving in Rome by train from Florence just for the day. We have a late afternoon Vatican tour (purchased on Vatican website direct.) It begins around 3:30 and lasts 2 hours without the happy hour portion. So, over by 6:00 PM at theआणखी latest, I'm hoping.

Is it difficult to get a taxi from the Vatican to the train station? Is the FreeNow app the best way or is it safe to take one of the taxis at a taxi stand close to the Vatican? I don't want to get ripped off like I've read happens to so many when catching a taxi at the Vatican. I've not made our train reservations yet back to Florence from Rome. How much time do you feel it would be to get a taxi to get to the train station to catch a train? Should I allow about two hours between the Vatican tour end and the train? I'm so stressed over this!! Thank you!

comments.comment_text: Your tour will probably be canceled before you arrive, if it isn’t just get an Uber black. An E or S class Merc will collect you and drop you off, haven’t waited more than 5 minutes for the car to arrive so don’t stress on timing. You can also book tours out the front from vendors.

after others chime in about the taxis, keep in mind that there is a metro station a couple of blocks north of the Vatican and another station at the Piazza Republican, which is a couple of blocks from the train station.
I would just use the Metro, jump on at Termini and off at Ottaviano, a few blocks away from the Vatican.
I was often overcharged by taxi drivers on my Italy trip, but who cares! Compared to the cost of your total trip it’s a very small amount. I was just happy to be able to get a taxi.
In case taxi option won't work - Metro line A, from station Ottaviano (5 minutes walk from Vatican) directly to Termini. Ticket costs 1.50 EUR, can be purchased in the machine underground.

I just found this again, I had lost it but found it just now. I think it's good info:

How to Find a Taxi at the Vatican

There are NO TAXIS at the taxi stand in front of St. Peter's Basilica.

Not one. Anywhere in sight. I presume this is a security measure.

If you exit the Vatican Museums through the same door where you entered, you will see a taxi stand there to your left.

If you are exiting St. Peter's Basilica, to find the closest taxi stand, walk out of St. Peter's Square. Walk around the iron barriers, hugging the colonnade.

When you've almost come to the Swiss Guard, take a left on via delle Fornaci.

Walk along that street, taking the little pedestrian underpass, and once you exit the underpass, you will see the taxi stand on your left.

It's less than a five minute walk from St. Peter's Square.
I used Uber so the price was set
Take the metro. It’s so easy. There’s an entrance to the metro right outside the Vatican and it’ll take you right to Roma termini.

Today we went from our Airbnb in the centre of Rome (via Sforza) to the vatican and we paid 12 euros by a Uber (actually the car was a taxi). It was fast (it was 7 in the morning), easy and cheap (we are a family of 4). If you use a Uber you pay through the app and you see how much you are due to pay in advance.

I also recommend the metro as the simplest option since you won’t have luggage. You’ll be taking Metro Line A - the stops by the Vatican are Cipro and Ottaviano. When you enter the station, look for the signs for “direzione Anagnina.” (Ie the east-bound direction) Get off at “Termini” which is the main train station for your train back to Florence. The ride to Termini is only about 15 min by metro. If you take a cab it will likely be 30 min because you are cutting right through the heart of Rome at a busy hour. Altogether I would still allow about an hour and half between the end of the tour and the train departure time in case of unforeseen delays, pit stops for bathrooms or refreshments etc.
There are plenty of things on the daily to be stressed about… getting a taxi 🚖 is not one IMHO 🤷🏽

The Freenow app is the easiest to use. It was easier to find a taxi during late hours compared to Uber. It will also give you an estimate cost and duration. Download it and register ahead of time.
One more tip if you don’t get a taxi right away, cancel that trip quickly and reorder. You won’t be charged and get a taxi.

We were there a month ago and there was a lot of construction going in there, making it difficult to maneuver. Apparently it was kind of a long term mess for awhile. Just a FYI.

We just caught an Uber to make it a bit easier and got on the phone with the driver when our pickup point didn't work because of the construction and traffic congestion in the area. That might be the way to go for you.

comments.comment_text: Most gold jewelery in Italy is made in Arezzo. Every year the city exports around 2.5 billion euros in jewelery.
Valenza (Piedmont) is famous for jewelry! My aunt and granny used to buy there! In the surrounding you can visit the old sinagogue in Casale Monferrato, and drink Monferrato hills wine.
